text.text: We're excited to be hosting you in the DevTools and Swift channel this week! You can find the full schedule of Q&As for DevTools and Swift by visiting the <https://apps.apple.com/us/app/apple-developer/id640199958 | Apple Developer app> and <https://developer.apple.com/events/ask-apple/questions-and-answers/ | website>.
If you haven’t already, please take a moment to familiarize yourself with <https://developer.apple.com/news/?id=vpbyzfg4 | how Q&As will work>.

We want to make sure these spaces are helpful and welcoming for everyone — developers and Apple employees alike. Please review and follow the <https://developer.apple.com/events/policy/online-event-attendance-policy/ | attendance policy>.

messages.text: <@U03V30M0C1K> added a workflow to this channel: *Ask Apple - devtools-and-swift*.

elements.text: added a workflow to this channel:
Ask Apple - devtools-and-swift

messages.text:
We’re excited to kick off a week of Q&A activities! Our first activity is :rocket: *Performance,* :battery: *Power, and* :scales: *Stability*, beginning at 10:00am Pacific on Wednesday. We love fast app launches, smooth scrolling, power efficiency, and all of the developer tools that make it possible!

We hope you can join us! If you’re unable to tune-in live, you can begin sending in your questions related to these topics now. Select the :heavy_plus_sign: icon from the lower left, and find the *Ask A Question* workflow. Type in your question and it will be delivered directly to the team. We’ll answer as many questions as we can during the 60 minute event on Wednesday.

elements.text: We’re excited to kick off a week of Q&A activities! Our first activity is

messages.text:
Good morning all! We'll be starting our Q&A on the topic of performance, power, and stability in just about *1 hour from now* at 10 AM PDT! :rocket:

We'll be answering your questions about optimizing your app's use of CPU, memory, energy, and disk. You can also ask about gaining insights into your app's performance with tools like Instruments, Xcode Organizer, MetricKit, and `XCTest` metrics. These videos are a great primer for the topic of today's Q&A:
• <https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2022/10082/|Track down hangs with Xcode and on-device detection>
• <https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2022/110363/|Improve app size and runtime performance>
• <https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2021/10087/|Diagnose Power and Performance regressions in your app>
• <https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2022/10083/|Power down: Improve battery consumption>
• <https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/tech-talks/10855/|Explore UI animation hitches and the render loop>
• <https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2021/10180/|Detect and diagnose memory issues>
To ask a question, select the :heavy_plus_sign: icon from the lower left, and select the "Ask a question" workflow. Type in your question to deliver it directly to the team. We’ll answer as many questions as we can during the 60 minute event this morning.

messages.text:
<@U046T40FY58> asked
> Thanks for doing this Q&A! I have a question regarding the metrics collected by the system and exposed through Xcode (Battery Usage, Memory, Scrolling, etc). For our app we can see some entries of very old versions but nothing recent (6+ months old). 
> 
> Is it possible that if you have added a custom MXMetricManager to the app, then the data is not sent to Xcode/App Store Connect?

elements.text: asked

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Thanks for doing this Q&A! I have a question regarding the metrics collected by the system and exposed through Xcode (Battery Usage, Memory, Scrolling, etc). For our app we can see some entries of very old versions but nothing recent (6+ months old). \n\nIs it possible that if you have added a custom MXMetricManager to the app, then the data is not sent to Xcode\/App Store Connect?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: MXMetricManager (and MetricKit usage generally) have no impact on your data in the Organizer. The Organizer has thresholds set that prevent noisy data from being delivered - if you file a Feedback at <http://feedbackassistant.apple.com|feedbackassistant.apple.com> with your app's Bundle ID and name, we can take a look and see why you might not be seeing data!

elements.text: MXMetricManager (and MetricKit usage generally) have no impact on your data in the Organizer. The Organizer has thresholds set that prevent noisy data from being delivered - if you file a Feedback at
feedbackassistant.apple.com
with your app's Bundle ID and name, we can take a look and see why you might not be seeing data!

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Thanks for the clarification! I have filed FB11705093 :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text: Thanks for the clarification! I have filed FB11705093

messages.text:
<@U047CK00V8Q> asked
> We need to share data between several push notification extensions, and when we set app mode to groups, we sometimes get a crash. TestFlight gives the following information:
> 
> 
> Exception Type: EXC_CRASH (SIGKILL)
> Exception Codes: 0x0000000000000000, 0x0000000000000000
> Exception Note: EXC_CORPSE_NOTIFY
> Termination Reason: RUNNINGBOARD 0xdead10cc
> 
> Which is not really helpful. Any advice on determining the reason and fixing the problem?

elements.text: asked

elements.Raw:
{"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"We need to share data between several push notification extensions, and when we set app mode to groups, we sometimes get a crash. TestFlight gives the following information:


Exception Type: EXC_CRASH (SIGKILL)
Exception Codes: 0x0000000000000000, 0x0000000000000000
Exception Note: EXC_CORPSE_NOTIFY
Termination Reason: RUNNINGBOARD 0xdead10cc

Which is not really helpful. Any advice on determining the reason and fixing the problem?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
Hi there! This termination reason (0xdead10cc) is due to a file or database like being held by your app/extension at suspension time. For more information on app and extension lifecycles, check the following on <http://developer.apple.com|developer.apple.com>:

> <https://developer.apple.com/library/archive/documentation/General/Conceptual/ExtensibilityPG/ExtensionOverview.html>
> <https://developer.apple.com/documentation/uikit/app_and_environment/managing_your_app_s_life_cycle?language=objc>

attachments.fallback: App Extension Programming Guide: Understand How an App Extension Works
attachments.title: App Extension Programming Guide: Understand How an App Extension Works
attachments.text: Describes how to develop an app extension, which is an executable that adds functionality to other apps.

elements.text: Hi there! This termination reason (0xdead10cc) is due to a file or database like being held by your app/extension at suspension time. For more information on app and extension lifecycles, check the following on
developer.apple.com

messages.text:
<@U04673E7B2P> asked
> Is the Singleton pattern ideal for dependency injection? 
> In our case we have lots of dependencies and, although it's very convenient, we were wondering if it could affect directly the app's performance or power usage.

elements.text: asked

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Is the Singleton pattern ideal for dependency injection? \nIn our case we have lots of dependencies and, although it's very convenient, we were wondering if it could affect directly the app's performance or power usage."}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
First of all — always profile first and optimize with data.

From a CPU usage perspective, I'd be surprised if singleton patterns would be an issue unless there's an _extremely_ frequent call-site that repeatedly looks up the singleton, but this kind of thing should show up in a time profile.

From a memory usage perspective, singletons usually exist forever, so if they're building up large state over time that could certainly be an issue. The <https://developer.apple.com/documentation/xcode/gathering-information-about-memory-use|Memory Graph Debugger> might be a good way of seeing what memory your app's holding on to, and if it's related to singletons which are held in global variables (in `__DATA`). Note though that the globals themselves are unlikely to be an issue if they're just pointers to objects, but if you'd like to see what's in your `__DATA` you can run `symbols <binary>`

you can run
symbols <binary>

messages.text:
Hey all! We're getting a few questions about crash reports and understanding the reasons for unexpected app termination, so I'll start a quick thread about it here!
:thread:

elements.text: Hey all! We're getting a few questions about crash reports and understanding the reasons for unexpected app termination, so I'll start a quick thread about it here!

slackdump_thread_replies.text: We have a brilliant talk from WWDC 2020 that goes into the most common reasons for app terminations and the tools to understand the reasons behind them. This is a great place to start! <https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2020/10078/>

messages.text:
<@U045ZGP2QCV> asked
> When starting unit tests, Xcode 14 beachballs for ~50 seconds before compiling starts, regardless of a macOS or iOS scheme. Why? How could we troubleshoot or avoid this? 
> 
> Potentially irrelevant: Our codebase is SwiftUI + Composable Architecture, with ~100 lines in the App target and then a hierarchy of 5 SPM packages, with one core package of ~60 targets.

elements.text: asked

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"When starting unit tests, Xcode 14 beachballs for ~50 seconds before compiling starts, regardless of a macOS or iOS scheme. Why? How could we troubleshoot or avoid this? \n\nPotentially irrelevant: Our codebase is SwiftUI + Composable Architecture, with ~100 lines in the App target and then a hierarchy of 5 SPM packages, with one core package of ~60 targets."}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Hi there! Thanks for the report. In order for our team to dig into this further, we would greatly appreciate if you could file a feedback at <http://feedbackassistant.apple.com|feedbackassistant.apple.com>, and include a sysdiagnose while Xcode is beachballing.

elements.text: Hi there! Thanks for the report. In order for our team to dig into this further, we would greatly appreciate if you could file a feedback at
feedbackassistant.apple.com
, and include a sysdiagnose while Xcode is beachballing.

messages.text:
<@U0464REQQCU> asked
> Regarding app hangs: We appreciate Xcode 14's new runtime warnings around possible app hangs/UI unresponsiveness such as this one from `CoreLocation`s `CLLocationManager.locationServicesEnabled()`:
> 
> > This method can cause UI unresponsiveness if invoked on the main thread. Instead, consider waiting for the `-locationManagerDidChangeAuthorization:` callback and checking `authorizationStatus` first.
> 
> We're also observing app hangs from `HKHealthStore`'s `-authorizationStatusForType:`, however, Xcode does not produce any runtime warnings for them specifically. Is it known/expected that `-authorizationStatusForType:` may lead to UI unresponsiveness and if so, what are possible workarounds?

elements.text: asked

elements.Raw:
{"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Hi there,
that's great feedback! As you noticed, Xcode 14 shows new runtime warnings about some API misuse. For now, many of these are special-cased warnings about commonly misused APIs, but we haven't audited all API yet.

We don't have a HealthKit engineer with us right now, so I can't answer whether "},{"type":"text","text":"authorizationStatusForType","style":{"code":true}},{"type":"text","text":" from "},{"type":"text","text":"HKHealthStore","style":{"code":true}},{"type":"text","text":" should be safe to run in terms of hangs or there is an async alternative to use instead. But it would be great to have this information.

If you see hangs being caused by "},{"type":"text","text":"authorizationStatusForType","style":{"code":true}},{"type":"text","text":" can you please file a feedback via "},{"type":"link","url":"http://feedbackassistant.apple.com","text":"feedbackassistant.apple.com"},{"type":"text","text":" to ask for either the hang to be fixed or a runtime warning to be produced for API misuse?

If you feel the documentation isn't clear on how to use it, that's also great feedback to report!"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Will file feedback

elements.text: Will file feedback

messages.text:
<@U045ZGP2QCV> asked
> A missing link for App Store Connect analytics is accessibility data. If there are far fewer than expected sessions with ax features enabled, notifying the developer would benefit users, Apple's ecosystem, and said developer's market penetration.
> 
> As these are highly sensitive data, collection, storage, and analytics is best done by a mindful third party (i.e., Apple). 
> 
> As a financial institution (lender), we don't want to be anywhere near a user's medical information, but we do want to flag accessibility problems and regressions beyond manual testing and UI snapshot testing. We're putting together a program that takes a number of uncommon measures to ensure fully anonymized accessibility state collection, but it's more involved than most organizations will probably to do on a whim. We'd gladly scrap it if Apple offered an alternative.

elements.text: asked

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Hey Ryan, are you looking for something like the percent of your users that have ax on per day? Can you please file a Feedback (<https://feedbackassistant.apple.com>) with your request, including what you had in mind that you'd conclude from this data and importance to you, and then paste the FB ID back here?

elements.text: Hey Ryan, are you looking for something like the percent of your users that have ax on per day? Can you please file a Feedback (
) with your request, including what you had in mind that you'd conclude from this data and importance to you, and then paste the FB ID back here?

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
FB11705152

Yes, or number of sessions, but more on a feature level, e.g., VoiceOver, DynamicType size, etc.

It would also be OK to not report a percentage unless it's sufficiently large (e.g., 30% dark mode or 10% reduced brightness), as seeing "1% VoiceOver" might actually demotivate developers and defeat the purpose. In those cases, simply a "as expected" or "problematically low" label is good enough.

elements.text:
FB11705152

Yes, or number of sessions, but more on a feature level, e.g., VoiceOver, DynamicType size, etc.

It would also be OK to not report a percentage unless it's sufficiently large (e.g., 30% dark mode or 10% reduced brightness), as seeing "1% VoiceOver" might actually demotivate developers and defeat the purpose. In those cases, simply a "as expected" or "problematically low" label is good enough.

messages.text:
<@U046JND8CKB> asked
> Hi, is there any absolutely basic code that you think should be included in most apps that help with loading or keeping performance as fast as possible? Just a bit beyond the basic of changing the boilerplate error code which crashes the app to some useful error handling and slightly less basic including concurrency when needed. Or is it always pretty much dependent on the app?

elements.text: asked

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Hi, is there any absolutely basic code that you think should be included in most apps that help with loading or keeping performance as fast as possible? Just a bit beyond the basic of changing the boilerplate error code which crashes the app to some useful error handling and slightly less basic including concurrency when needed. Or is it always pretty much dependent on the app?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
Hi there! Thanks for your question. In general, iterating on your code and using tooling to measure performance is a great start. We strongly recommend instrumenting XCTest Performance tests and using Instruments throughout your development process to measure performance quantitatively. You can find a great primer talk on how to use these tools and more here:

<https://developer.apple.com/videos/play/wwdc2021/10181/>

I also recommend taking a look through the following article for a great overview on some critical concepts for maintaining good performance:

<https://developer.apple.com/documentation/metrickit/improving_your_app_s_performance>

messages.text:
Thank you for joining us for this Q&A! It was a blast :rocket:. Our Q&A activities in this channel have now concluded. We wish we could have answered all your questions! If we weren’t able to get to your question, here are some great ways to keep in touch:

• File feedback! Let us know what’s not clear or what behavior seems a bit off by using the Feedback Assistant app or going to: <http://feedbackassistant.apple.com|feedbackassistant.apple.com> 
• Submit a TSI! Developer Technical Support engineers are available to give you code-level support. You can submit a TSI here: <https://developer.apple.com/support/technical/> 
• Ask a question on the Apple Developer Forums: <https://developer.apple.com/forums/>
Thank you so much for making this such an engaging week!

messages.text:
<@U045MLXB6UX> asked
> What can we do if our app can't use all the cores but then hangs/stalls the machine (can't make new threads)? FB10893202

elements.text: asked

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"What can we do if our app can't use all the cores but then hangs\/stalls the machine (can't make new threads)? FB10893202"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
hey Steven - thanks for filing that FB and apologies on the delay getting back to you on it.

Thanks for the sample code as well. If you have a way to reliably exercise it into the state you're seeing to reproduce, that would be really helpful.

We also made a fix in Ventura with dispatch queues that we think could be your issue. Could you see if you could reproduce there as well?

If you can reproduce and are familiar, attaching using lldb and printing the state of your input queue and dispatch_get_global_queue(QOS_CLASS_DEFAULT, 0) would help the dispatch team narrow this down.

elements.text:
hey Steven - thanks for filing that FB and apologies on the delay getting back to you on it.

Thanks for the sample code as well. If you have a way to reliably exercise it into the state you're seeing to reproduce, that would be really helpful.

We also made a fix in Ventura with dispatch queues that we think could be your issue. Could you see if you could reproduce there as well?

If you can reproduce and are familiar, attaching using lldb and printing the state of your input queue and dispatch_get_global_queue(QOS_CLASS_DEFAULT, 0) would help the dispatch team narrow this down.
